results.headline: Singles, City and Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of HappyThankYouMorePlease

results.summary_short: Josh Radnor of “How I Met Your Mother” wrote and directed this comedy about young romance and an escapee from foster care.

results.headline: From Hottie to Homely, Transformed by a Witch

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beastly

results.summary_short: Teenage love breaks out in “Beastly,” a fairy tale remade.

results.headline: A Farewell to This Life, and All Its Ghosts
results.display_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives

results.summary_short: Those who insist on a linear narrative may find themselves puzzled by “Uncle Boonmee.” But encountered in a certain frame of mind, it can produce something close to bliss.

results.headline: For One Young Muslim the Path to Faith Is Rocky

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mooz-lum

results.summary_short: A Muslim student wrestles with faith in Qasim Basir’s film “Mooz-Lum,” with Evan Ross, Roger Guenveur Smith and Nia Long.

results.headline: On a Mission, but Not From God

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drive Angry

results.summary_short: In “Drive Angry,” Nicolas Cage, driving a muscle car while he tries to save a baby, has a hellish accountant on his trail.

results.headline: Between Heaven and Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Of Gods and Men

results.summary_short: “Of Gods and Men” is based on the true story of a group of French Cistercian Trappist monks caught up (and ultimately killed) in the violence that engulfed Algeria in the 1990s.

results.headline: Three to a Bed, but No Funny Stuff

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heartbeats

results.summary_short: Two friends, a young woman and man, pursue the same blond-curled object of desire in the Québécois director Xavier Dolan’s romantic, cinematically extravagant “Heartbeats.”

results.headline: ‘A Good Man’: A Sideline in the Sex Industry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Good Man

results.summary_short: “A Good Man,” a documentary by Safina Uberoi, follows Chris Rohrlach, an Australian farmer who opens a legal brothel.

results.headline: Like Old Times

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Over the Hill Band

results.summary_short: Three Belgian septuagenarians look to resurrect their old singing group in the dramedy “The Over the Hill Band.”

results.headline: Man-Child in the Promised Land, for a Whole (Pant! Pant!) Week

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hall Pass

results.summary_short: In the Farrelly brothers’ “Hall Pass” two men suffering marital fatigue get a week off from their marriages. Let the ogling commence.

results.headline: The Redemption of a Racist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grace Card

results.summary_short: David Evans, an optometrist whose previous arts experience involved producing passion plays at a Memphis Christian church, makes his directorial debut with “The Grace Card.”

results.headline: Bye-Bye, Happiness; Life Is a Trap

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything Strange and New

results.summary_short: In Frazer Bradshaw’s “Everything Strange and New” a couple is gripped by an overwhelming sense of resignation and certainty that their happy days are behind them.

results.headline: A Black Widow Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 7 Sins Forgiven

results.summary_short: Vishal Bhardwaj’s “7 Khoon Maaf,” a meandering black widow tale, has plenty of art. But it floats around, ungrounded in anything like emotional reality.

results.headline: One Giant Family
results.display_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son

results.summary_short: Martin Lawrence plays Big Momma, his F.B.I.-agent-in-drag character, for the third time, in “Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son.”

results.headline: ‘We Are What We Are’: They Are What They Eat

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are What We Are

results.summary_short: Jorge Michel Grau’s “We Are What We Are” follows the fortunes of a group of cannibals in Mexico City after its diseased leader dies in a shopping mall.

results.headline: Drugs, Death and Downward Mobility in Baltimore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Putty Hill

results.summary_short: Matt Porterfield’s “Putty Hill” is a moody fusion of fiction and documentary, set in a working-class neighborhood in Baltimore.

results.headline: Discovering Columbus’s Exploitation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Even the Rain

results.summary_short: A movie within a movie, “Even the Rain” draws parallels between the European colonialism of antiquity and more modern forms of exploiting indigenous populations.

results.headline: Disappearing People, Leaving a Lot of Clothes Behind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanishing on Seventh Street

results.summary_short: The something wicked that comes creeping like night in “Vanishing on 7th Street,” seemingly sucking people right out of their homes, cars and clothes, arrives without warning.

results.headline: Me, My Doppelgänger and a Dunk in the River

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unknown

results.summary_short: In Jaume Collet-Serra’s “Unknown,” Liam Neeson plays a botanist who wakes up in the hospital without any identification and with a missing wife (January Jones).

results.headline: ‘Now & Later’ Explores Sex and Politics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Now & Later

results.summary_short: “Now & Later,” starring Shari Solanis, combines graphic sex and politics, though it’s hard to pay attention to one of the two (guess which).
